info.author: Nuxeo and contributors
classifiers: License :: OSI Approved :: GNU General Public License (GPL)
info.description:
CPS is an extensive collaborative Web content management system (CMS) 
implemented on top of Zope and the CMF, that enables organizations to easily, 
quickly and efficiently implement collaborative portals (intranet, extranet or 
internet) and workflow- oriented business applications. 
 
CPS Provides, among other features: 
 
    * Collaborative work and publication spaces (you may need to be 
authenticated with the right access level to access these URLs) 
    * Document versionning, that allows a document to be published in one 
version and still worked on in another one 
    * Group-based, directory-backed user and roles management 
    * A configurable Portal interface, with a web- and accessibility-standards 
compliant default look and feel (you will need to be authenticated with the 
right access level to access this URL) 
    * Notifications on many kinds of events happening on the system 
    * An WYSIWYG editor for portal look and feel  
    * Many user-level services, like a Webmail, Forums, shared Calendars, 
Newsletters and Mailing Lists, etc. 
    * Many powerful developers- and webmaster-level services, including support 
for creating your own document types, your own workflows, etc.
info.keywords: CPS, Zope, CMF, ECM, groupware, framework, Nuxeo
info.name: CPS
info.summary: Advanced and full featured Open Source ECM framework
info.html_description:
CPS is an extensive collaborative Web content management system (CMS)
implemented on top of Zope and the CMF, that enables organizations to easily,
quickly and efficiently implement collaborative portals (intranet, extranet or
internet) and workflow- oriented business applications.

CPS Provides, among other features:

* Collaborative work and publication spaces (you may need to be
authenticated with the right access level to access these URLs)
* Document versionning, that allows a document to be published in one
version and still worked on in another one
* Group-based, directory-backed user and roles management
* A configurable Portal interface, with a web- and accessibility-standards
compliant default look and feel (you will need to be authenticated with the
right access level to access this URL)
* Notifications on many kinds of events happening on the system
* An WYSIWYG editor for portal look and feel
* Many user-level services, like a Webmail, Forums, shared Calendars,
Newsletters and Mailing Lists, etc.
* Many powerful developers- and webmaster-level services, including support
for creating your own document types, your own workflows, etc.
